docs.title: YAICLI: Your AI Assistant in Command Line
docs.text:
YAICLI is a powerful yet lightweight command-line AI assistant that brings the capabilities of Large Language Models (LLMs) like GPT-4o directly to your terminal. Interact with AI through multiple modes: have natural conversations, generate and execute shell commands, or get quick answers without leaving your workflow.

Supports both standard and deep reasoning models across all major LLM providers.

docs.title: 🔄 Multiple Interaction Modes
docs.text:
• 💬 Chat Mode: Engage in persistent conversations with full context tracking
  • 🚀 Execute Mode: Generate and safely run OS-specific shell commands
  • ⚡ Quick Query: Get instant answers without entering interactive mode

docs.title: 🧠 Smart Environment Awareness
docs.text:
• Auto-detection: Identifies your shell (bash/zsh/PowerShell/CMD) and OS
  • Safe Command Execution: Verification before running any command
  • Flexible Input: Pipe content directly (cat log.txt | ai "analyze this")

docs.title: 🔌 Universal LLM Compatibility
docs.text:
• OpenAI-Compatible: Works with any OpenAI-compatible API endpoint
  • Multi-Provider Support: Support multiple providers

docs.title: 💻 Enhanced Terminal Experience
docs.text:
• Real-time Streaming: See responses as they're generated with cursor animation
  • Rich History Management: Manage histories with 500 entries by default
  • Syntax Highlighting: Beautiful code formatting with customizable themes

docs.title: 🛠️ Developer-Friendly
docs.text:
• Layered Configuration: Environment variables > Config file > Sensible defaults
  • Debugging Tools: Verbose mode with detailed API tracing

docs.title: 📚 Function Calling
docs.text:
• Function Calling: Enable function calling in API requests
  • Function Output: Show the output of functions

docs.title: 📚 MCP Calling
docs.text:
• MCP Calling: Call LLM with MCP tools
  • MCP Output: Show the output of MCP tools

docs.title: Contributing
docs.text: Contributions to YAICLI are welcome! This page outlines how you can help improve the project.

docs.title: Ways to Contribute
docs.text:
There are several ways to contribute to YAICLI:

  • Bug Reports: Open an issue describing the bug and how to reproduce it
  • Feature Requests: Suggest new features or improvements
  • Code Contributions: Submit a pull request with your changes
  • Documentation: Help improve or translate the documentation

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• Python 3.10 or higher
  • uv, the Python project manager (https://github.com/astral-sh/uv)
  • Git
  • A GitHub account

docs.title: Setting Up Your Development Environment
docs.text:
1. Fork the repository on GitHub
  2. Clone your fork locally: 
    git clone https://github.com/YOUR-USERNAME/yaicli.git
cd yaicli
  3. Create a virtual environment: 
    uv venv
source venv/bin/activate  # On Windows: venv\Scripts\activate
  4. Install dependencies for development: 
    uv sync --all-extras

docs.title: Code Style
docs.text:
YAICLI follows these style guidelines:

  • Use Ruff for code formatting
  • Follow PEP 8 style guidelines
  • Write docstrings for all public functions, classes, and methods

docs.title: Testing
docs.text:
Before submitting a PR, make sure to run the tests:

pytest

docs.title: Pull Request Process
docs.text:
1. Create a new branch for your feature or bugfix
  2. Make your changes
  3. Run the tests to ensure everything works
  4. Update the documentation if necessary
  5. Submit a pull request describing your changes

docs.title: Adding a New Provider
docs.text:
To add a new LLM provider to YAICLI:

  1. Create a new file in yaicli/llms/providers/ named after your provider (e.g., my_provider.py)
  2. Implement the provider class following the interface pattern of existing providers
  3. Add the provider to the provider registry in yaicli/llms/providers/__init__.py
  4. Update any configuration-related code to recognize the new provider
  5. Add tests for your provider in the tests/llms/ directory

docs.title: Documentation
docs.text:
When contributing documentation:

  1. Follow the existing structure
  2. Use Markdown for all documentation files
  3. Test changes locally using MkDocs: 
    mkdocs serve

docs.title: Frequently Asked Questions
docs.text: This page addresses common questions and issues encountered when using YAICLI.

docs.title: What is YAICLI?
docs.text: YAICLI is a command-line interface for interacting with Large Language Models (LLMs). It allows you to chat with AI assistants, generate shell commands, and get quick answers directly from your terminal.

docs.title: What LLM providers are supported?
docs.text: YAICLI supports multiple providers including: - OpenAI (GPT-4o, GPT-3.5, etc.) - Google Gemini - Claude (Anthropic) - Cohere - Mistral - Ollama - Many others (see Providers Overview)

docs.title: Is an internet connection required?
docs.text: Yes, for most providers. YAICLI communicates with LLM APIs that require internet access. However, you can use local models with providers like Ollama.

docs.title: How is my data handled?
docs.text: YAICLI stores your conversation history locally. Your prompts and API responses are sent to the LLM provider you configure, according to their privacy policies. No data is sent to YAICLI developers.

docs.title: Why am I getting "command not found" after installing?
docs.text:
Make sure your Python scripts directory is in your PATH. Try these solutions:

# Option 1: Find the installation location
which ai

# Option 2: Add to PATH (add to .bashrc or .zshrc)
export PATH="$HOME/.local/bin:$PATH"

docs.title: How do I set up my API key?
docs.text: You can set your API key in three ways: 1. In the config file (~/.config/yaicli/config.ini) 2. As an environment variable (export YAI_API_KEY="your-key") 3. Using a .env file in your project directory

docs.title: Can I use multiple API keys for different providers?
docs.text:
Yes! You can create separate configuration sections or switch providers using environment variables:

# Use OpenAI
export YAI_PROVIDER=openai
export YAI_API_KEY=sk-...

# Use Gemini (in another session or after changing vars)
export YAI_PROVIDER=gemini
export YAI_API_KEY=AI...

docs.title: How do I save a chat session?
docs.text:
In chat mode, use the /save command followed by a title: 

💬 > /save "Python Tips"

Or start a named session that will be automatically saved: 

ai --chat "Python Tips"

docs.title: How do I control output formatting?
docs.text:
Use the --justify option to control text alignment: 

ai --justify center "Write a poem about AI"

Options include: default, left, center, right, and full.

docs.title: How do I disable streaming responses?
docs.text:
Use the --no-stream flag or set STREAM=false in your config: 

ai --no-stream "What is the capital of France?"

docs.title: How do I change the code highlighting theme?
docs.text:
Set the CODE_THEME in your config file: 

CODE_THEME = monokai  # or any other Pygments theme

docs.title: How do I execute shell commands safely?
docs.text:
Use shell mode with the -s or --shell flag: 

ai -s "Find all PNG files in the current directory"
You'll be prompted to review and optionally edit commands before execution.

docs.title: Why am I getting API errors?
docs.text:
Common causes: - Invalid API key - Rate limits or quota exceeded - Network connectivity issues - Incompatible model for your provider

Usually you will see a error message in output like 429 too many requests.

Try running with the verbose flag to see detailed error information: 

ai --verbose "Test query"

docs.title: How do I fix "SSL Certificate Verification Failed"?
docs.text:
This typically happens in corporate environments with SSL inspection. Try:

# Not recommended for security reasons, but may be necessary
export PYTHONWARNINGS="ignore:Unverified HTTPS request"
export REQUESTS_CA_BUNDLE=/path/to/corporate/certificate.pem

docs.title: How do I update YAICLI?
docs.text:
# Using pip
pip install --upgrade yaicli

# Using pipx
pipx upgrade yaicli

# Using uv
uv tool upgrade yaicli

docs.title: Why are my non-ASCII characters displaying incorrectly?
docs.text:
Make sure your terminal supports UTF-8 and has a compatible font. On Windows, you might need to: 

chcp 65001  # Set console code page to UTF-8

docs.title: How do I create custom roles?
docs.text:
Create a new role: 

ai --create-role "SQL Expert"

Then use it: 

ai --role "SQL Expert" "Optimize this query"

docs.title: Can I use function calling?
docs.text:
Yes, enable function calling with: 

ai --enable-functions "Check the weather in New York"

Install default functions: 

ai --install-functions

docs.title: How do I create custom functions?
docs.text:
Add your function definitions to: 

~/.config/yaicli/functions/

See the Usage Configuration Guide for details on function configuration.

docs.title: How do I use MCP (Multi-provider Chain Protocol)?
docs.text:
Enable MCP with: 

ai --enable-mcp "Search for the latest AI research papers"

Configure MCP in: 

~/.config/yaicli/mcp.json

docs.text: We welcome contributions! See the contributing guidelines for details on: - Reporting bugs - Suggesting features - Submitting pull requests - Code standards

docs.title: Where can I report bugs or request features?
docs.text: Please submit issues on the GitHub repository.

docs.title: Getting Started with YAICLI
docs.text: YAICLI is a powerful yet lightweight command-line AI assistant that brings the capabilities of Large Language Models (LLMs) like GPT-4o directly to your terminal. This guide will help you get up and running quickly.

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
After installation, you can start using YAICLI immediately:

# Get a quick answer
ai "What is the capital of France?"

# Start an interactive chat session
ai --chat

# Generate and execute shell commands
ai --shell "Create a backup of my Documents folder"

# Generate code snippets (default is Python)
ai --code "Write a function to sort a list"

docs.title: First-time Setup
docs.text:
1. Run ai once to generate the default configuration file
  2. Edit ~/.config/yaicli/config.ini to add your API key
  3. Customize other settings as needed

docs.title: Configuration
docs.text:
YAICLI uses a layered configuration approach: - Environment variables (highest priority) - Config file (~/.config/yaicli/config.ini) - Sensible defaults (lowest priority)

You can view the default configuration template with:

ai --template

docs.title: Direct Queries
docs.text:
Get quick answers without entering interactive mode:

ai "What is quantum computing?"

docs.title: Interactive Chat Mode
docs.text:
Start a persistent conversation with context tracking:

ai --chat "Python programming"

docs.title: Command Generation
docs.text:
Get AI to generate and optionally execute shell commands:

ai --shell "Find all large files in my home directory"

docs.title: Code Generation
docs.text:
Generate code snippets with syntax highlighting:

ai --code "Create a web scraper for news headlines"

docs.title: Installation Guide
docs.text: YAICLI can be installed using several methods. Choose the one that best suits your needs.

docs.text: • Python 3.10 or higher

docs.title: Using pip (Recommended)
docs.text:
The simplest way to install YAICLI is using pip:

pip install yaicli

docs.title: Using pipx (Isolated Environment)
docs.text:
If you prefer to install the tool in an isolated environment:

pipx install yaicli

docs.title: Using uv (Faster Installation)
docs.text:
For faster installation with the uv package manager:

uv tool install yaicli

docs.title: Installing with Optional Dependencies
docs.text: YAICLI offers several optional dependency groups that you can install based on your needs:

docs.title: All Dependencies
docs.text:
# Using pip
pip install 'yaicli[all]'

# Using uv
uv tool install 'yaicli[all]'

docs.title: Specific Provider Support
docs.text:
# Using pip
pip install 'yaicli[ollama,cohere,doubao,huggingface,gemini,mistral]'

# Using uv
uv tool install 'yaicli[ollama,cohere,doubao,huggingface,gemini,mistral]'

git clone https://github.com/belingud/yaicli.git
cd yaicli
pip install .

docs.text:

ai --help

This should display the help information for YAICLI.

After installation, run the tool once to generate the default configuration file:

ai

Then edit the configuration file located at ~/.config/yaicli/config.ini to add your API key and customize settings:

# Open with your preferred editor
nano ~/.config/yaicli/config.ini

docs.title: Conversation & History Management
docs.text: YAICLI provides robust conversation history management features to help you maintain context and revisit past interactions. This page explains how the history system works and how to manage your chat history.

docs.title: Command History
docs.text: YAICLI maintains a history of your commands and interactions, allowing you to: - Search through previous commands - Reuse past queries - Keep track of your AI conversations

docs.title: History Storage
docs.text:
By default, command history is stored in: - Linux/macOS: ~/.yaicli_history - Windows: %USERPROFILE%\.yaicli_history

The history file uses a simple text format with each command on a new line.

docs.title: History Size
docs.text:
You can configure the maximum number of history entries to retain:

[core]
MAX_HISTORY=500

Or using an environment variable:

export YAI_MAX_HISTORY=1000

docs.title: Viewing History
docs.text:
In interactive mode, use the /his command to view your command history:

💬 > /his
Chat History:
1 User: What is quantum computing?
    Assistant: Quantum computing is a type of computation...
2 User: What are qubits?
    Assistant: Qubits (quantum bits) are the basic...

docs.title: Searching History
docs.text:
Use Ctrl+R to search through your command history:

  1. Press Ctrl+R
  2. Type part of a previous command
  3. Press Ctrl+R again to cycle through matching results
  4. Press Enter to select the current match

docs.title: Auto-Suggestion
docs.text:
YAICLI can suggest commands based on your history as you type. Enable this feature in your config:

[core]
AUTO_SUGGEST=true

When enabled, YAICLI will show suggestions in light gray text as you type. Press the right arrow key to accept a suggestion.

docs.title: Chat Persistence
docs.text:
Chat sessions can be persistent or temporary:

  • Persistent Session: Automatically saved with a title
  • Temporary Session: Not saved unless explicitly requested

To start a persistent chat session:

ai --chat "Python programming"

To convert a temporary session to persistent:

💬 > /save "Python programming"
Chat saved as: Python programming

docs.title: Chat Storage Location
docs.text:
Chat history is stored in: - Default: A temporary directory specific to your system - Configurable through CHAT_HISTORY_DIR setting

[core]
CHAT_HISTORY_DIR=/path/to/custom/directory
MAX_SAVED_CHATS=20

docs.title: Listing Saved Chats
docs.text:
To list your saved chat sessions:

# From command line
ai --list-chats

# From interactive mode
💬 > /list

This displays a numbered list of saved chats with their creation dates.

docs.title: Loading Saved Chats
docs.text:
You can load saved chats in two ways:

# From command line (using the chat title)
ai --chat "Python programming"

# From interactive mode (using the chat index from /list)
💬 > /load 3

docs.title: Deleting Saved Chats
docs.text:
To delete a saved chat:

# From interactive mode
💬 > /del 3

This will permanently remove the selected chat session.

docs.title: Context Window
docs.text: YAICLI automatically manages the conversation context based on: - The model's context window limitations - The number of messages in the current session - The complexity and length of each message

docs.title: Clearing Context
docs.text:
To clear the current conversation context:

💬 > /clear

This removes all previous messages from the current session's context but does not delete saved chat history.

docs.title: History File Format
docs.text:
The chat history files are stored as JSON with this structure:

{
  "title": "Chat Title",
  "created_at": "2024-06-01T12:00:00Z",
  "updated_at": "2024-06-01T13:30:00Z",
  "messages": [
    {
      "role": "user",
      "content": "User message here"
    },
    {
      "role": "assistant",
      "content": "Assistant response here"
    }
  ]
}

docs.title: Manual History Editing
docs.text:
You can manually edit the history files:

  1. Navigate to your chat history directory
  2. Open the JSON file with any text editor
  3. Modify as needed (keeping the JSON structure intact)
  4. Save the file

docs.title: History Migration
docs.text:
When upgrading YAICLI, history files are automatically migrated to newer formats if needed. If you're experiencing issues with history after an upgrade, try:

# Backup your history
cp ~/.yaicli_history ~/.yaicli_history.bak

# Remove the history file to create a fresh one
rm ~/.yaicli_history

docs.title: Disabling History
docs.text:
You can disable command history saving completely by setting:

[core]
MAX_HISTORY=0

docs.title: Best Practices
docs.text:
1. Regular Cleaning: Periodically review and delete unnecessary chat sessions
  2. Meaningful Titles: Use descriptive titles for your persistent chats
  3. Context Awareness: Clear context when switching topics within the same session
  4. Backup: Occasionally backup your chat history directory for important conversations

docs.title: Prompt Template System
docs.text: YAICLI features a powerful and flexible prompt template system that allows you to define custom roles and behaviors for your AI assistant. This page explains how to use and customize the prompt system.

docs.title: Understanding Roles
docs.text: In YAICLI, a "role" is a predefined set of instructions, preferences, and behaviors assigned to the AI. Roles help guide how the AI responds to your queries.

docs.title: Default Roles
docs.text: YAICLI comes with a built-in DEFAULT role that provides a solid foundation for general-purpose interactions. This role instructs the AI to be helpful, accurate, and concise.

docs.title: Creating Custom Roles
docs.text:
You can create custom roles to tailor the AI's behavior for specific tasks or domains:

# Create a new role through interactive prompting
ai --create-role "SQL Expert"

# You'll be asked to provide a description for this role

When creating a role, you'll be prompted to describe how the AI should behave in that role. For example:

Please provide a description for the SQL Expert role:

You are an expert SQL database engineer with deep knowledge of database 
optimization, query design, and best practices across multiple SQL dialects 
including MySQL, PostgreSQL, SQLite, and Microsoft SQL Server. 

When asked about SQL, you should:
1. Consider the specific dialect if mentioned, or clarify which dialect you're using
2. Provide optimized queries with explanations of your optimization choices
3. Consider indexing, query planning, and performance implications
4. Format SQL with proper indentation and capitalization of keywords

docs.title: Using Custom Roles
docs.text:
Once created, you can use your custom roles:

# Use in direct query mode
ai --role "SQL Expert" "Optimize this query: SELECT * FROM users WHERE active = true"

# Use in chat mode
ai --chat --role "SQL Expert"

# Use in shell command mode
ai --shell --role "DevOps Engineer" "Set up a cronjob"

docs.title: Managing Roles
docs.text:
YAICLI provides commands to manage your roles:

# List all available roles
ai --list-roles

# View a specific role's description
ai --show-role "SQL Expert"

# Delete a role
ai --delete-role "SQL Expert"

docs.title: Role Storage
docs.text:
Custom roles are stored in: - Linux/macOS: ~/.config/yaicli/roles/ - Windows: C:\Users\<username>\.config\yaicli\roles\

Each role is saved as a JSON file with the role name.

docs.title: Setting a Default Role
docs.text:
You can set a default role in your configuration file:

[core]
DEFAULT_ROLE=SQL Expert

Or using an environment variable:

export YAI_DEFAULT_ROLE="SQL Expert"

docs.title: Role Structure
docs.text:
Roles are defined as JSON files with the following structure:

{
  "name": "Role Name",
  "description": "Detailed instructions for the AI...",
  "created_at": "2024-06-01T12:00:00Z",
  "updated_at": "2024-06-01T12:00:00Z"
}

docs.title: Creating Roles Manually
docs.text:
You can create roles manually by adding JSON files to the roles directory:

  1. Create a file named role_name.json in the roles directory
  2. Add the role structure as shown above
  3. Restart YAICLI or run ai --list-roles to see your new role

docs.title: Role Modification Warning
docs.text:
By default, YAICLI will warn you when attempting to modify built-in roles. To disable this warning:

[core]
ROLE_MODIFY_WARNING=false

docs.title: Best Practices for Writing Role Descriptions
docs.text:
For the most effective custom roles:

  1. Be Specific: Clearly define the expertise and focus area
  2. Set Boundaries: Specify what the AI should and should not address
  3. Format Guidelines: Include preferred output formats, styles, or conventions
  4. Examples: When helpful, include examples of desired responses
  5. Context: Add relevant domain knowledge or context that might help the AI

docs.title: Technical Writer
docs.text:
You are a technical writer specializing in creating clear, concise documentation.

When responding:
1. Use plain language and avoid jargon unless necessary
2. Structure content with logical headings and lists
3. Focus on practical examples and use cases
4. Include both beginner and advanced perspectives
5. Use consistent terminology throughout

For code examples, include comments explaining key concepts.

docs.title: Data Analyst
docs.text:
You are a data analyst with expertise in statistics, data visualization, and data manipulation.

When analyzing data or answering queries:
1. Consider statistical validity and assumptions
2. Suggest appropriate visualization techniques
3. Recommend efficient data processing approaches
4. Highlight potential biases or limitations
5. Provide code examples in Python using pandas, matplotlib, or similar libraries

Always emphasize data integrity and ethical considerations in your analysis.

docs.title: System Administrator
docs.text:
You are a system administrator experienced with Linux, Windows, and cloud environments.

When providing assistance:
1. Prioritize security best practices
2. Consider compatibility across different systems
3. Provide step-by-step instructions with explanations
4. Suggest monitoring and maintenance practices
5. Mention potential pitfalls or issues to watch for

For shell commands, explain what each command does and any flags or options used.

docs.title: Advanced Features
docs.text: YAICLI includes several advanced features to enhance your interaction with AI models.

docs.title: Chat Persistent Sessions
docs.text:
YAICLI allows you to save and manage chat sessions:

# Start a temporary chat session
$ ai --chat

# Start a persistent chat session with a title
$ ai --chat "Python programming help"

# List saved chat sessions
$ ai --list-chats

docs.title: Managing Chat Sessions
docs.text: In a chat session, you can use these commands: - /save <title> - Save the current session with a title - /list - List all saved sessions - /load <index> - Load a previously saved session - /del <index> - Delete a saved session

docs.title: Persisting Chat Sessions
docs.text:
When you start a chat with a title, the session is automatically saved to disk:

$ ai --chat "check disk usage"
Chat title: check disk usage

The session will be persisted to CHAT_HISTORY_DIR by default.

docs.title: Role Management
docs.text:
YAICLI supports custom roles to guide AI behavior:

# Create a new role
ai --create-role "Python Expert"

# List all roles
ai --list-roles

# Show a role
ai --show-role "Python Expert"

# Delete a role
ai --delete-role "Python Expert"

# Use a specific role
ai --role "Python Expert" "How do I use decorators?"

docs.title: Function Calling
docs.text:
YAICLI supports function calling, enabling AI models to call functions to accomplish tasks:

# Install default functions
ai --install-functions

# List available functions
ai --list-functions

# Enable function calling in queries
ai 'check the current dir total size' --enable-functions

You can also define custom functions by adding them to ~/.config/yaicli/functions/.

docs.title: MCP (Machine Comprehension Protocol)
docs.text:
MCP allows AI models to use external tools:

# Enable MCP in queries
ai 'What is the latest exchange rate between BTC and USD?' --enable-mcp

Configure MCP tools in ~/.config/yaicli/mcp.json.

docs.title: Basic Usage
docs.text: YAICLI offers multiple ways to interact with AI models directly from your command line.

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
Get a quick answer.

ai "What is the capital of France?"

Start an interactive chat session 

ai --chat

Generate and execute shell commands 

ai --shell "Create a backup of my Documents folder"

Generate code snippets, default in Python 

ai --code "Write a Python function to sort a list"

Read stdin from pipe 

cat app.py | ai "Explain what this code does"

Debug with verbose mode 

ai --verbose "Explain quantum computing"

docs.title: CLI Shortcuts & Hotkeys
docs.text: YAICLI offers a rich set of keyboard shortcuts and interactive features to enhance your command-line experience. This page covers all available shortcuts and interactive functionalities.

docs.title: Global Shortcuts
docs.text:
These shortcuts work in all interactive modes:

Shortcut Description Ctrl+C or Ctrl+D Exit the application Tab Toggle between Chat/Execute modes Ctrl+R Search command history ↑/↓ Navigate through command history Ctrl+L Clear the screen Ctrl+A Move cursor to beginning of line Ctrl+E Move cursor to end of line Ctrl+U Clear charactors before cursor Ctrl+W Delete word before cursor

docs.title: History Navigation
docs.text:
When searching history with Ctrl+R:

Shortcut Description Ctrl+R Cycle through matching history items Enter Select current history item Esc Cancel history search

docs.title: Interactive Commands
docs.text:
YAICLI provides special commands that begin with a slash (/) or an exclamation mark (!):

Command Description /help or /? Show help message /clear Clear the current conversation history /his Show command history /list List all saved chat sessions /save <title> Save the current chat session with a title /load <index> Load a saved chat session /del <index> Delete a saved chat session /exit Exit the application /mode chat\|exec Switch between chat and execute modes !<command> Execute a shell command directly

With !<command>, you can execute a shell command directly without leaving the interactive mode. For example, !ls -al will list files in the current directory, !git status will show the git status, etc.

docs.title: Auto-Suggestion
docs.text:
YAICLI offers auto-suggestions based on your command history. As you type, it shows light gray text suggesting completions from your history:

  • Press → (right arrow) to accept the full suggestion
  • Continue typing to ignore the suggestion
  • Press Ctrl+→ to accept the next word of the suggestion

To disable auto-suggestions, set AUTO_SUGGEST=false in your configuration.

docs.title: Multi-line Input
docs.text:
To enter multi-line input:

  1. Type your text normally
  2. Press Alt+Enter or Esc+Enter to add a new line
  3. Continue adding lines as needed
  4. Press Enter on an empty line to submit

This is useful for:

  • Writing multi-line code examples
  • Composing complex prompts
  • Structuring lists or tables

docs.title: Command Editing
docs.text:
When in Execute mode and reviewing a suggested command:

Option Description e Edit the command before execution y Execute the command as is n Cancel execution

When editing a command:

  • The full command is presented in an editable field
  • Make your changes and press Enter to execute
  • Press Esc to cancel the edit

docs.title: Visual Indicators
docs.text:
YAICLI uses visual indicators to help you understand the current state:

Indicator Meaning 💬 > Chat mode prompt 🚀 > Execute mode prompt Cursor animation Processing your request Syntax highlighting Code in responses

docs.title: Interactive Mode Commands
docs.text:
When in interactive chat or shell mode, you can use these special commands:

Command Description /help or /? Show help message /clear Clear conversation history /his Show command history /list List saved chats /save <title> Save current chat with title /load <index> Load a saved chat /del <index> Delete a saved chat /exit Exit the application /mode chat\|exec Switch between chat and execute modes /add <path> Add file or directory to context /context <subcmd> Manage context (alias: /ctx)

docs.title: Context Management Commands
docs.text:
The /add and /context commands help you manage files and directories in the conversation context:

Command Description /add <path> Add a file or directory to the persistent context /context list or /ctx list List all items in current context /context clear or /ctx clear Remove all items from context /context add <path> Add item to context (same as /add) /context remove <path> or /ctx remove <path> Remove specific item from context

Context Features:

  • Persistent: Items added with /add stay in context for the entire session
  • Smart reading: Files are read and formatted for AI consumption
  • Directory support: Directories are scanned recursively (2 levels deep by default)
  • Auto-ignores: Skips .git, node_modules, __pycache__, .venv, etc.
  • Flexible matching: Use partial paths or filenames for removal

Example:

💬 > /add src/main.py
Added file to context: /path/to/src/main.py

💬 > /add tests/
Added directory to context: /path/to/tests/

💬 > /context list
┏━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┓
┃ Type   ┃ Path                          ┃
┡━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┩
│ FILE   │ src/main.py                   │
│ DIR    │ tests/                        │
└────────┴───────────────────────────────┘

💬 > /context remove main.py
Removed from context: /path/to/src/main.py

💬 > /ctx clear
Context cleared.

docs.title: @ File References
docs.text:
In addition to persistent context, you can temporarily reference files using the @ symbol directly in your queries:

Syntax:

# Single file reference
@filename

# Multiple files
@file1.py @file2.py

# Paths with spaces (use quotes)
@"my document.txt"
@'path with spaces/file.md'

How it works:

  1. Type @ followed by a file path
  2. Press Tab for auto-completion and file browser
  3. Use arrow keys to select files
  4. The file content is automatically included in that message only
  5. References are replaced with filenames in the final message

Example:

# Quick file analysis
💬 > @README.md Summarize this project

# Compare files
💬 > @config.json @config.example.json What changed?

# Use with quotes for spaces
💬 > @"my notes.txt" Create a todo list from these notes

# Path completion
💬 > @src/ma[Tab]
# Shows: src/main.py, src/math.py, etc.

Differences from /add:

Feature /add @ reference Duration Entire session Single message only Storage Persistent context Temporary inclusion Best for Codebases you'll discuss repeatedly Quick one-time file checks Management Manual add/remove Automatic per message

docs.title: Configuration Guide
docs.text: YAICLI uses a layered configuration system to store your preferences and API keys. This guide explains all available configuration options and how to customize them.

docs.title: Configuration Hierarchy
docs.text:
YAICLI follows this priority order for configuration:

  1. Command-line arguments (highest priority)
  2. Environment variables
  3. Configuration file
  4. Default values (lowest priority)

docs.title: Location
docs.text:
The default configuration file is located at:

  • Linux/macOS: ~/.config/yaicli/config.ini
  • Windows: C:\Users\<username>\.config\yaicli\config.ini

docs.title: First-time Setup
docs.text:
1. Run ai once to generate the default configuration file
  2. Edit the file to add your API key and customize settings

docs.title: Viewing Default Configuration
docs.text:
To view the default configuration template:

ai --template

docs.title: Configuration File Structure
docs.text:
The configuration file uses the INI format with the following sections:

[core]
PROVIDER=openai
BASE_URL=
API_KEY=
MODEL=gpt-4o

DEFAULT_ROLE=DEFAULT
# auto detect shell and os (or specify manually, e.g., bash, zsh, powershell.exe)
SHELL_NAME=auto
OS_NAME=auto

# true: streaming response, false: non-streaming
STREAM=true

# LLM parameters
TEMPERATURE=0.3
TOP_P=1.0
MAX_TOKENS=1024
TIMEOUT=60
REASONING_EFFORT=

# Interactive mode parameters
INTERACTIVE_ROUND=25

# UI/UX
CODE_THEME=monokai
# Max entries kept in history file
MAX_HISTORY=500
AUTO_SUGGEST=true
# Print reasoning content or not
SHOW_REASONING=true
# Text alignment (default, left, center, right, full)
JUSTIFY=default

# Chat history settings
CHAT_HISTORY_DIR=<tmpdir>/yaicli/chats
MAX_SAVED_CHATS=20

# Role settings
# Set to false to disable warnings about modified built-in roles
ROLE_MODIFY_WARNING=true

# Function settings
# Set to false to disable sending functions in API requests
ENABLE_FUNCTIONS=true
# Set to false to disable showing function output in the response
SHOW_FUNCTION_OUTPUT=true

# MCP settings
ENABLE_MCP=false
SHOW_MCP_OUTPUT=false

docs.title: Environment Variables
docs.text:
All configuration options can be set using environment variables with the YAI_ prefix:

# Set API key via environment variable
export YAI_API_KEY="your-api-key"

# Use a different model
export YAI_MODEL="gpt-3.5-turbo"

# Disable streaming
export YAI_STREAM="false"

Environment variables take precedence over the configuration file settings.

docs.text: See the Providers section for detailed configuration options for each supported LLM provider.

docs.title: File Context Management
docs.text: YAICLI provides powerful file context management capabilities that allow you to include files and directories in your AI conversations. This helps the AI understand your codebase, configuration files, documentation, and any other relevant context.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
There are two ways to include files in your conversations:

  1. Persistent Context (/add): Add files/directories that stay in context for the entire session
  2. Temporary References (@): Reference files on-the-fly for a single message

docs.title: Persistent Context
docs.text: Use the /add command to add files or directories to your session context. These items remain available throughout your conversation until you remove them.

docs.title: Adding Files
docs.text:
# Add a single file
/add src/main.py
# Output: Added file to context: /path/to/src/main.py

# Add a directory (scans recursively)
/add tests/
# Output: Added directory to context: /path/to/tests/

# Add multiple files
/add config.yaml README.md

docs.title: Removing Context Items
docs.text:
# Remove by exact path
/context remove /path/to/src/main.py

# Remove by filename (partial match)
/context remove main.py

# Clear all context
/context clear

docs.title: Complete Command Reference
docs.text: Command Alias Description /add <path> - Add file/directory to context /context list /ctx list List all context items /context clear /ctx clear Remove all items /context add <path> - Same as /add /context remove <path> /ctx rm Remove specific item

docs.title: Temporary @ References
docs.text: For quick, one-time file inclusion, use the @ symbol directly in your messages.

docs.title: Basic Usage
docs.text:
# Reference a single file
@README.md What is this project about?

# Reference multiple files
@src/main.py @config.yaml Explain the architecture

# The AI sees the file contents and responds based on them

docs.title: Paths with Spaces
docs.text:
Use quotes for filenames or paths containing spaces:

@"my document.txt" Summarize this

@'path with spaces/file.md' What does this do?

docs.title: Auto-completion
docs.text:
Type @ and press Tab to browse files:

💬 > @src/[Tab]
# Shows file browser:
# src/main.py
# src/utils.py
# src/config/

Use arrow keys to navigate and select files.

docs.title: File Reading Process
docs.text:
1. File Detection: YAICLI checks if the path exists
  2. Type Check: Determines if it's a file or directory
  3. Content Reading:
  4. Files: Read entire content
  5. Directories: Recursively scan (2 levels deep by default)
  6. Formatting: Content is formatted as Markdown code blocks
  7. Submission: Formatted content is sent to the AI as a system message

docs.title: Smart File Handling
docs.text:
Binary Files: Automatically skipped - Images: .png, .jpg, .jpeg, .gif, .ico - Archives: .zip, .tar, .gz - Compiled: .pyc, .pdf

Size Limits: Files larger than 1MB are skipped

Encoding: UTF-8 with error replacement for non-UTF-8 characters

docs.title: Directory Scanning
docs.text:
When you add a directory, YAICLI:

  1. Scans files recursively (default: 2 levels deep)
  2. Skips hidden files (starting with .)
  3. Ignores common patterns:
  4. .git/
  5. __pycache__/
  6. .venv/, venv/
  7. node_modules/
  8. .idea/, .vscode/
  9. .DS_Store

Example Directory Structure:

project/
├── src/
│   ├── main.py
│   └── utils/
│       ├── helpers.py
│       └── config.py
├── tests/
│   └── test_main.py
└── .git/          # Skipped
└── node_modules/  # Skipped

/add src/
# Includes:
# - src/main.py
# - src/utils/helpers.py
# - src/utils/config.py

docs.title: Codebase Analysis
docs.text:
# Add entire source directory
/add src/

💬 > Explain the architecture of this codebase
# AI now has full visibility into src/

docs.title: Configuration Review
docs.text:
# Multiple config files
/add .env
/add docker-compose.yml
/add config.yaml

💬 > Are there any security issues in this configuration?
# AI reviews all config files together

docs.title: Debugging
docs.text:
# Add error log and source file
/add error.log
/add src/handler.py

💬 > Why is this error happening in handler.py?
# AI correlates the error with source code

docs.title: Documentation
docs.text:
# Quick reference for documentation
@api-docs.md @docs/api-guide.md Implement this endpoint

# vs persistent context for long sessions
/add docs/

💬 > Help me implement user authentication
💬 > Now add password reset
💬 > Finally, add email verification
# docs/ stays in context for entire session

docs.title: When to Use /add (Persistent)
docs.text:
• Working on a specific feature: Add relevant source files
  • Code reviews: Include all files being reviewed
  • Debugging sessions: Keep error logs and source files available
  • Documentation: Reference docs while implementing features
  • Multi-step tasks: Avoid repeating file references

docs.title: When to Use @ (Temporary)
docs.text:
• Quick questions: One-time file checks
  • Comparing files: @file1.json @file2.json
  • Minimal context: Don't clutter the conversation
  • Ad-hoc analysis: Quick look at a file

docs.title: Tips
docs.text:
1. Be Specific: Add only relevant files to avoid context bloat
  2. Clean Up: Remove items with /context remove when done
  3. Check Context: Use /context list to see what's active
  4. Use Quoted Paths: For files with spaces, use @"path"
  5. Combine Both: Use /add for core files, @ for temporary references

docs.title: Example Workflow
docs.text:
# Start a coding session
ai --chat

# Add core source files
/add src/
/add config.yaml

💬 > Add a new user registration endpoint

# Add a specific test file temporarily
@tests/test_auth.py Write tests for this

# Reference documentation once
@docs/api-spec.md Follow these specs

# Context still has src/ and config.yaml
💬 > Update the password validation

# Clean up when done
/context clear

docs.title: Limitations
docs.text:
• File Size: Files > 1MB are skipped
  • Binary Files: Automatically filtered out
  • Directory Depth: Limited to 2 levels by default
  • Context Window: Total content limited by your model's context window
  • Session Scope: Context doesn't persist across different ai invocations

docs.title: File Not Found
docs.text:
💬 > /add nonexistent.py
Error: Path does not exist: /path/to/nonexistent.py

Solution: Use relative paths from current directory or absolute paths

docs.title: Binary File Warning
docs.text:
💬 > @image.png
Warning: Cannot include @image.png: [Binary file omitted]

Expected behavior: Binary files are automatically skipped

docs.title: Too Large Warning
docs.text:
💬 > @large-file.log
Warning: Cannot include @large-file.log: [File too large: 2097152 bytes - omitted]

Solution: Split the file or extract relevant portions

docs.title: Context Too Long
docs.text:
If the AI stops responding or behaves unexpectedly, your context may be too large.

Solution: 

/context list
/context remove <unnecessary-files>

docs.title: Related Features
docs.text:
• Function Calling: Use functions to interact with the file system
  • Pipe Input: cat file.txt | ai "analyze this"
  • MCP Tools: External tools for file system operations
  • History Management: Save and restore conversations with context

docs.title: Mode Switching (Chat / Execute)
docs.text: YAICLI offers multiple interaction modes to suit different needs. This page explains each mode and how to switch between them.

docs.title: Available Modes
docs.text: YAICLI has three primary interaction modes:

docs.title: 1. Chat Mode (💬)
docs.text:
Chat mode provides a natural conversation experience with the LLM, maintaining context and formatting responses with markdown.

Features: - Full conversation history and context tracking - Markdown and code formatting - Reasoning display for complex queries - Persistent chat storage and management

Best for: - Extended conversations - Complex questions requiring context - Learning and exploration

docs.title: 2. Execute Mode (🚀)
docs.text:
Execute mode specializes in generating and safely running shell commands based on natural language descriptions.

Features: - OS-specific command generation - Command review and editing before execution - Command output display - Safe execution with confirmation

Best for: - System administration tasks - File operations - Command discovery - Automating repetitive tasks

docs.title: 3. Quick Query Mode (Default)
docs.text:
The default non-interactive mode gives you quick answers without entering a persistent session.

Features: - Direct answers to questions - Support for piped input - Fast responses with minimal overhead

Best for: - One-off questions - Quick information lookups - Script integration

docs.title: Command Line Switches
docs.text:
Use these flags when starting YAICLI:

# Start in chat mode
ai --chat "Optional chat title"

# Start in execute mode
ai --shell "Create a backup script"

# Quick query (default mode)
ai "What is the capital of France?"

docs.title: Interactive Mode Switching
docs.text: When in interactive mode (chat or execute), you can switch modes in several ways:

docs.title: Using Tab Key
docs.text: Press the Tab key to toggle between Chat and Execute modes.

docs.title: Using Commands
docs.text:
Type /mode followed by the mode name:

/mode chat   # Switch to chat mode
/mode exec   # Switch to execute mode

docs.title: Visual Indicators
docs.text: The prompt changes to indicate your current mode: - Chat mode: 💬 > - Execute mode: 🚀 >

docs.title: Chat Mode Behavior
docs.text:
In chat mode: - The AI responds conversationally with rich formatting - Context is maintained between interactions - Input is treated as a conversation prompt

Example: 

💬 > Tell me about quantum computing
Assistant:
Quantum computing uses quantum bits (qubits) that can exist in multiple 
states simultaneously due to superposition...

docs.title: Execute Mode Behavior
docs.text:
In execute mode: - The AI interprets input as a request for a command - Generates appropriate commands for your OS and shell - Displays the command for review before execution

Example: 

🚀 > Find all PDF files in my Downloads folder
Assistant:
find ~/Downloads -name "*.pdf"

│ find ~/Downloads -name "*.pdf"        │

docs.title: Chat Persistence
docs.text:
When starting a chat session with a title, the conversation is automatically saved:

ai --chat "Python tips"

A chat started without a title is treated as temporary but can be saved later:

💬 > /save "Python tips"
Chat saved as: Python tips

You can list, load, and manage saved chats:

💬 > /list
Saved chats:
1. Python tips (2023-07-01)
2. Work project (2023-06-28)

💬 > /load 1
Loading chat: Python tips
